In the UK, a project to turn
traffic noise into Biofuel
is being implemented.  Exploited and obtained
positive initial results,
these hexagonal blocks are placed
along both sides of busy roads in
London, they are actually
microalgae farms with speakers attached to catch
sound and have wires.  The metal is
specially designed to amplify sound
at a frequency of 400 Hz that is beneficial for the
growth of Algae. The algae will then be
used to create sustainable compounds
including project biofuels.  This product
is called LG Wave. In addition to noise, LG
Wave also absorbs CO2, microscopic particles and
sunlight, creating an ideal environment
for cultivating algae. It will
convert CO2 gas into oxygen and filter the
air in the environment.  According to Erway's assessment, urban markets
help increase biomass availability
by 30 minutes and reduce costs by 27 minutes compared
to traditional Algae farms.
